title: 103_hr3464
content: The Act is titled the "Comprehensive Arson Deterrence and Fire Containment Act of 1993." It authorizes $15,000,000 for the modernization or replacement of the Modular Airborne Fire Fighting System used by the United States Forest Service to improve fire fighting response time. The Forest Service, in consultation with fire chiefs and experts, will study ways to improve airborne fire fighting response time and report to Congress within a year. Additionally, the Act increases criminal penalties for arsonists. The amendment to section 844 of title 18, United States Code, increases penalties for malicious use of fire or explosives on federal property. Offenders could face fines or up to 10 years in prison, with specific circumstances leading to harsher punishments. The amendment to section 844 of title 18, United States Code, increases penalties for malicious use of fire or explosives on federal property. Offenders could face fines or up to 10 years in prison, with specific circumstances leading to harsher punishments, including fines and imprisonment for offenses exceeding $1,000,000 in damage or placing lives in jeopardy. The amendment to section 844 of title 18, United States Code increases penalties for malicious use of fire or explosives on federal property. Offenders could face fines or up to 10 years in prison, with specific circumstances leading to harsher punishments, including fines and imprisonment for offenses exceeding $10,000,000 in damage or placing lives in jeopardy. If personal injury or damage exceeding $25,000,000 results from the offense, the offender faces a fine and imprisonment of 10 to 40 years. In cases of death, the offender may face a fine, imprisonment exceeding 25 years, or even the death penalty. The offender may face imprisonment for more than 25 years or life, and potentially the death penalty, for certain offenses. Interstate commerce laws are also amended to increase the maximum imprisonment term. The punishment for certain offenses may include a fine or imprisonment for up to 10 years, or both. If the damage exceeds $1,000,000, the offender could face a fine and imprisonment for 5 to 20 years. If the damage caused by the offense exceeds $1,000,000, the offender faces a fine and imprisonment for 5 to 20 years. If the damage exceeds $10,000,000 or places a person's life in jeopardy, the offender could be imprisoned for 8 to 30 years. If personal injury results or damage exceeds $25,000,000, the offender faces a fine and imprisonment for 10 to 40 years. In case of death, the offender may face a fine and imprisonment exceeding 25 years or life, and potentially the death penalty. Whoever recklessly engages in conduct that would be prohibited by subsection (f) or (i) of this section, resulting in the destruction of a dwelling or harm to a person, may face imprisonment for more than 25 years, or life, and potentially the death penalty. Whoever recklessly engages in conduct prohibited by subsection (f) or (i) of this section, resulting in a dwelling's destruction or injury to a person, may face a fine, imprisonment up to one year, or both. If not imprisoned, probation with 400-2000 hours of community service is mandatory. In juvenile cases, similar penalties apply. In cases where a person is convicted under this section, the court may sentence them to probation with a requirement of 400-2000 hours of community service. Juveniles found delinquent for similar conduct must spend a week in a residential institution and perform community service. The court may sentence individuals convicted under this section to probation with 100-1000 hours of community service. The court may sentence individuals to probation with 100-1000 hours of community service, and juvenile delinquents may also be required to spend time in a residential institution. The Forest Service will study federal legal impediments to clearing fire hazards and report to Congress within a year. Defense conversion will strengthen private firefighting capabilities. The Secretary of Defense, in consultation with the Federal Aviation Administration, will report to Congress on utilizing excess military cargo and private fire fighting contractors for fire fighting purposes. Additionally, they will explore reforming Federal aviation regulations to maximize the use of planes for fire fighting. The Forest Service, in consultation with fire chiefs and experts, will study building roads and backup power for water supply in national forests to enhance fire fighting. Results will be reported to Congress within a year. SEC. 8. REVENUE OFFSET. The Secretary of Agriculture will reduce below-cost direct loans of the Farmers Home Administration by 5% for fiscal years 1994 through 1998.
